bioghist.p: Helen Burwell Chapin (1892-1950) attended Bryn Mawr College, graduating in 1915. She was an expert in Asian art. Her interest in Chinese art began when she worked in the Oriental Department of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts from 1917 to 1924 and again from 1928 to 1929. She learned Chinese and began to travel to China, working for a time for the American Consulate in Shanghai. She also studied at the Tokyo Imperial Museum and the Toyo Bunko Library and studied Buddhist relics and temples in Korea. She received her master's degree from Mills College in 1935 and her Ph.D. from the University of California in 1940. During the Second World War, she worked as a Research Analyst for the Department of Justice. From 1946 to 1948 she was the Asiatic Arts and Monument Specialist with the Department of the Army stationed in Korea.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Helen Chapin. Materials include: correspondence with Ananda K. Coomaraswamy and his wife about Asian art and Chapin's career during the 1940s; photographs of Korean and Japanese temples, artworks, street scenes, landscapes, and people; notes on the architecture of various Buddhist sites in Korea; and notes on Asian art and on Chapin's own collection of art and books.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
